stem: Based on the patient's clinical presentation and lab results, complete the following sentence regarding the immediate nursing intervention:
template: The nurse should {{blank1}} due to the patient's elevated {{blank2}} level, indicating a critical need for immediate intervention.
options: administer a bolus of IV regular insulin
initiate oral hydration with a sports drink

blanks.correctOption: administer a bolus of IV regular insulin

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 14:00: Patient, a 16-year-old male, presented to the ED via ambulance. Initial assessment revealed altered mental status, Kussmaul respirations, and fruity breath odor. History of type 1 diabetes, but reports non-compliance with insulin regimen for the past week due to feeling ‘sick of it.’ 14:05: Patient is alert to name only. Reports abdominal pain and nausea. Denies vomiting. 14:10: IV access established. Initial blood glucose reading via glucometer is 580 mg/dL. 14:15: Physician notified and orders received per DKA protocol. 14:20: Continuous cardiac monitoring initiated. Urine ketones are large. Patient is currently receiving 0.9% normal saline at 250 mL/hr. Patient’s parents are at bedside and very concerned. Will continue to monitor vital signs and blood glucose levels closely per protocol. 14:25: Patient reports increased thirst.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Appears ill and weak. Neuro: Alert to name only, confused. HEENT: Dry mucous membranes, fruity breath odor. Cardiac: Tachycardic, regular rhythm. Respiratory: Kussmaul respirations, increased work of breathing. Abdomen: Soft, tender to palpation. Skin: Warm, dry, poor skin turgor.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: DKA Protocol: 1. Administer IV bolus of regular insulin 0.1 unit/kg. 2. Start continuous IV infusion of regular insulin at 0.1 unit/kg/hr. 3. Monitor blood glucose hourly. 4. Monitor electrolytes every 2 hours. 5. Administer IV fluids (0.9% NS) at 250 mL/hr. 6. Strict I&O.

rationale.correct: The patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of DKA, including hyperglycemia, acidosis, and dehydration. The priority is to lower the blood glucose level with IV insulin to prevent further complications such as cerebral edema or coma.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect options do not directly address the immediate life-threatening condition of severe hyperglycemia and acidosis in DKA. Oral hydration is insufficient for severe dehydration, and sodium bicarbonate is not typically the first-line treatment unless the pH is extremely low.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: Administering a bolus of IV regular insulin is the priority action because it rapidly lowers the blood glucose level, helping to correct the metabolic acidosis and prevent further complications of DKA. The insulin bolus will help facilitate glucose uptake into the cells, reducing the hyperglycemia.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The patient's significantly elevated blood glucose level (580 mg/dL) confirms the diagnosis of DKA and necessitates immediate intervention with IV insulin. This hyperglycemia is the primary driver of the osmotic diuresis, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances seen in DKA.

clinicalPearls: In DKA, always address the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) first, followed by addressing the hyperglycemia and acidosis with IV fluids and insulin.
Monitor potassium levels closely during insulin administration, as insulin drives potassium into the cells, potentially causing hypokalemia.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting options that address dehydration or electrolyte imbalances before addressing the hyperglycemia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the severity of the clinical findings. In DKA, severe hyperglycemia is the immediate threat to the patient's well-being.
